captions.text:
Hi, my name is Tim Cole, I'm with the Austin
Reptile Service and I've been keeping reptiles

amphibians for over forty years, and we're
going to talk about keeping smaller turtles

as pets. Actually, that's what I prefer. Because,
the larger water turtles are difficult to

keep, they require, for the most part, outdoor
ponds. So, your smaller species make better

pets. They're easier to care for, don't require
as much space. We're talking about Musk Turtles

and Mud Turtles, those are one of my favorites.
They average about four to six inches, in

fact, they don't require a lot of UV light,
they do very well in a fish aquarium. And,

if the fish have hiding places, actually do
well with the fish. I've been keeping Mud

and Musk turtles with tropical fish for over
ten years and haven't had any problems. I

think they've got more of a personality than
some of your turtles that get out and bask.

They spend all their time underwater walking
around on the logs and the rocks and they

feed very well on commercial diets or turtle
food, turtle pellets. Another species is a

Map turtle. If you get a male Map turtle,
they average about four to six inches, don't

get too big. They do get out and bask though.
They do require basking areas. Our Painted

turtles average about six inch shells, those
also make good turtles, they stay small. Some

of the,there's another turtle called a Reef
turtle, which is a southeast Asia turtle that

also does well in an aquarium. Don't get too
large. So, I would encourage you to get a

smaller species of turtle if you're looking
for a turtle pet. Keep in mind they don't

like to be handled, they don't want to be
picked up. Treat them like tropical fish.
Just observe them and leave them alone.

title: Pet Turtle Care : Mini Pet Turtles

comments.text:
This is a good video though some of his facts or incorrect. For instance:

1) If you buy a turtle from a young age and tame it, the reptile lets you 
handle it a lot more and can become like any other animal, a close friend 
who loves you

2) A small turtle can range to 8 inches before becoming a medium sized 
turtle - Not six inches -

3) The shells he was talking about, on average, go to 5-8 Inches not just 
border line 6". 

Sorry for nagging but I though for first time buyers out there that this 
would be very helpful.

But...

However it was a really nice video and you seemed to know a lot about your 
reptiles. :3﻿
